captions.text:
CHRIS HARRIS: Quite why a
nation with one of the

wettest, most miserable climates
on planet Earth would

become experts at making cars
with virtually no weather
protection is anyone's guess.

But we Brits are brilliant at
building small, lightweight
sports cars.

Caterham and Morgan are
the backbones of
this flourishing industry.

The new Morgan Three Wheeler
needs no introduction.

Out front is an SNS V twin,
displacing 1983 cc and

producing what Morgan estimates
to be 80 horsepower
at the rear wheel.
Call that 115 at the crank.

The little blob weight
around 550
kilograms, minus occupants.

The wheels are 19" in diameter
up front, but
just 3 and 1/2" wide.
The single rear is a 175/55.

There are planks of wood on
there somewhere, too.

At $30,000 basic, you could
argue that this car has no
real rivals.
[CAR ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: Let's discuss what
it is that makes this car
so special.

First things first, it's
missing a wheel.
Now, that is very significant.

It immediately means that the
car feels very, very special.

Just because of its dimensions,
and just because

everyone looks at you
wherever you go.

You could be driving around in a
bright pink Lamborghini with

an enormous penis painted on the
bonnet, and no one would

look at you because there's a
Morgan right next to you.

And that's the way things should
be because it really is
a special little car.

I find it really, really hard
to judge the Morgan Three

Wheeler as a driving
experience.

You almost can't judge it in
modern, conventional car terms

because it bears no resemblance
to the way most
modern cars drive.

Best way to describe it is to
treat it as an old car.

It's like getting in
a modern classic.

You therefore don't take any
limit with the amount of grip

its got, in terms of quartering
give or braking.

You think about every action,
and you don't
drive it that fast.

But even if you're going very
slowly, it's an event.

Everything about it
is memorable.

And what this big steering
wheel-- it's way
too high for me.

It's about the height
of my forehead.
The pedal box is adjustable.
It can come back to meet me.
But it's OK.

The seats, moderately
comfortable.

Quite nicely padded,
and quilted.

I could sit in it for
quite a long time.

I intended to cruise quite
fast in it yesterday.
And it was pretty tiring.

But then, that's not what
it's about, is it?

The steering's pretty
accurate.
It's quite light.

And even though it's unassisted,
it doesn't

actually have a vast amount
of feel to it.

The handling, well, the handling
is just hilarious.

Look how narrow those
front tires are.

You turn the car, and it turns
quite quickly in response.

But immediately that you
overstep the [INAUDIBLE] bit,

you get this very, very
benign under-steer.
So the front just washes out.

The problem being if you back
off and try and use a trailing

throttle to bring it round, it
doesn't come back too quickly.

So you have to be careful you
don't overstep the mark.

Make sure you've got some
space around you.

So if you over-steer, if you
[INAUDIBLE] it in first and
second gears.
It's hilarious.

T junctions, half throttle in
first gear on a slightly down
road is nicely sideways.
Full throttle, fully sideways.

Even in the dry, it lights
up that single
rear tire very easily.

And as you can see from some of
these shots, it'll slither

about in the most
hilarious way.

Although the way that front
tire squirms away from the

side wall and the heavy
cornering is a bit alarming
when you look at it on camera.

But you just don't realize it
when you're in the car.

I think it presents a really
pleasant face to the world.

It says, I'm a car enthusiast,
but I'm not too greedy.

It says, I love machinery,
but I'm not obsessed
about going too fast.

It says, I like the principles
of driving.
I like being busy.

I don't need to go too
fast to enjoy myself.

And it also says that
I don't mind looking
a little bit absurd.

I don't need to be in some
great, big extended phallus to
prove my wealth, or lack of.

The Morgan Three Wheeler
deconstructs driving as we

know it, and offers
a completely
different set of solutions.

And I rather like them,
particularly
when the sun's out.

There is great joy to be had
driving this car slowly, too.

That V twin SNS motor has
got loads of torque.

And I have to say, the
management of the feel, of the

throttle, the clutch pedal and
the gear lever is really,

really clever because you
can't help yourself just

quickly swooping up and down
the gear box, feeling a bit

more tall, and then just
rolling it around.
It's lovely, lovely stuff.
This is an MX5 gear box.
And it's a great choice.
Is the car fast?

Well, there is also some
joy in driving it fast.

For me, most of that joy is the
incongruity of something

that looks like this actually
covering ground quite quickly.

So the sort of naughtiness
factor.

Technically, going quite
quickly in it
can be quite alarming.

Dumping's OK, but
not that clever.

And it'll start to get almost
airborne in places.

And then, you're not quite sure
what it'll do when it

lands, because it's
missing a wheel.

But I suppose I'm missing the
point if I say I'm trying to

go really quickly in it because
it's not about that.

This celebrates motoring for
the sake of motoring.
Look at me!
I'm exposed to the elements.

I'm doing 34 miles an
hour at the moment.

And it feels more alive, at
least to me, than a 911 Turbo
does at 120.

If you drive this thing at 80
with the roof as it is and

with a pair of sunglasses on,
it feels like you're doing
about 700 miles an hour.
It's brilliant fun!

Yes, as you can tell,
I'm enjoying myself.

I can make a strong argument
for this being one of the

better recreational motor cars
I've driven in a while.
What a lovely thing.
You all know the Caterham.

It's pretty easy to simply book
the Crazy R500 version
for every test.

But this new super sports R
Model for $28,000 fully built
looks like a winner to me.

You get a two liter Duratech
pushing 118 horsepower, a 535

kilogram curb weight, a locking
rear differential, and

a smile so wide they'll think
you're Jack Nicholson.
[CAR ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: I need to slightly
expose myself as

being old because when I first
started doing this job, oh, I

don't know, very few years ago,
a fast Caterham had 120
horsepower.

A really fast Caterham
had 160 horsepower.

And a blinking quick Caterham
had around 200 horsepower.

This is the Caterham
Supersports.

It's a pretty delicious little
package, actually, for a snick
under $28,000 fully built.

A two liter Duratech, with what
I was told was supposed

to be a normal engine, not too
fast, it has 182 horsepower.
This car is really fast.

After the Morgan, it feels
a different world.

We're not comparing the two
cars light for light.

This is more a celebration,
as I said.
What else do we?
Get a locking diff.
We've only got five gears.
We're missing one.

We've got tiny little 175
section rears, and we've got

overs there, wherever
we want it.

We've also got a small hirsuite
man sitting in the

driver's seat, wondering why he
hasn't driven one of these

things in the last couple of
years because they are
absolutely brilliant.
[CAR ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: I sometimes wish
every car company that tries

to make a sports car or a
sporting version of a normal

car would spend time
in a Caterham.

On the one hand, it would teach
them so much about how a

car should feel underneath you
if you want to drive it to
really connect with it.

On the other hand, I fear
that they would say, we
just can't do that.

And then you've got something
that's as light, and as

clever, and as simple as the 7,
you just can't achieve it.
The steering is telepathic.
It's just gorgeous.

And even this, supposedly not
too aggressive example, to me

feels like a really,
really fast car.

It's on those little
CR500 tires.
It's got loads of grip.

You can enjoy driving
the Caterham slowly.

You're exposed to
the elements.

A lot less exposed
than the Morgan.

This feels like an XL Mercedes
after that thing.

But actually, the difference
here is that the Caterham

wants to be driven in
a different manner.

It wants you to behave a little
bit naughtily with it.
And I can't really resist it.
Look, you see?
I didn't mean to.

But suddenly, we're
accelerating!

And now we're going
faster, ha ha ha!
What a car.
And it's small on the road.
I've got options.

I've got so much space in
between the white lines.

I feel like I can place it
where I want to place it.

And even though the suspension
is good, it still feels a
little bit skittish.
So it feels alive on the road.

It's moving around
the whole time.

If I hit big bumps, it
gets deflected-- not
in an uncouth manner.

Not in a way that would lead me
to say that it's a bad car.

But just enough to keep
me on my toes.
The Caterham does that.
It keeps you on your toes.

Porsche and Ferrari don't make
a car that can give me the
experience I'm having now.

That's quite an important
distinction.
[CAR ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: Just love driving
them, absolutely love
driving it.
The braking performance--

I mean, you look at
those brake discs.
They're tiny.

But because of the lack of mass,
the thing just stops in

a way that any supercar couldn't
hope to match.
And you're on your own.
No ABS.
No nothing.
Sort your braking out.

If you get it right,
you're on.

If you get it wrong,
you're off.
[CAR ENGINE]
CHRIS HARRIS: I just love it.
I haven't driven one in ages.
I feel guilty.

I feel like I've let my car
loving genes down by not
getting my fix.

I should have been doing
this more regularly.
This is what it's all about.
[CAR ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: Each small amount
of throttle changes the
line in the corner.

You can get these little,
delicious slides, or not big,

ugly drifts like I do
the whole time.

But little, infinitesimal
slides-- they're lovely.

Oh, yeah, there is no
substitute for this.
There is no substitute.

The move to Ford Duratechs many
years ago gave a more

reliable engine, just a
little bit heavier,
and a lot more torque.

So I'm now in fourth gear,
40 miles an hour.
And I accelerate.
And I get instant urge.

And in a K Series car,
it would have been
a splatter at nothing.

I slightly miss the zaniness
of those VH PV K Series

engines, where they would
explode above 6,500 RPM and
fire off towards 8,500.

This is kind of all
done around 7,000.

But on the road, the
torque is lovely.

This five-speed gear box doesn't
feel quite as slick,
sometimes, to me as the six.

You've really got to help it
with a good amount of blip on

the way down through
the gears.

Reverse is a total
pain to get to.
But then, who cares?
And this simple dashboard.

I just feel like
I've come home.

Everything's spread about in
a fairly random fashion.
But you can reach it all.

And there's even a fag
lighter under there.

Can something so basic be worth
nearly 28,000 pounds?

If you love driving,
of course it can.
This is absolutely pure.

If you could, you wouldn't
buy amphetamine with
something in it.

You'd buy absolutely
pure amphetamine.
And that's what this car is.
It's been a tonic today.
I've loved, loved driving it.
Wow.
Maybe I should own one.

These cars remind us what
driving, and in a wider sense,
what motoring is all about.

It's about the sensations of
controlling a machine, not the

speed with which you
cover ground.

Although both of these cars
are very, very quick.

But it's also about
the adventure.

Wrap up warm and cover 150 early
morning miles in either,

and you'll be reminded why you
loved cars as a kid, why your

first time behind the wheel
was one of your defining
moments in life.

These, then, are the
essence of driving.

title: Morgan Three Wheeler and Caterham Seven: Brilliant British Flyweights - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
I bought a 230hp high-lift cam Zetec Caterham 7 last winter on a whim.  
Good whim it was, as the car is a total hoot to drive.  Same power-weight 
ratio as a Viper (though admittedly not nearly as fast as my Gen 4 
Viper ;)  But still crazy fast and crazy fun.  Kids literally scream in joy 
when you drive by in a car as ridiculous as a Lotus 7.  And a total chic 
magnet!  Driving an ordinary, exotic super car (Ferrari, or other) suggests 
to the world that you may need to (because of your other shortcomings)... 
but only gents completely secure in their manhood drive a car as silly as a 
Lotus 7.  Just because it is stupid fun!  And it's only a data-driven 
observation that I'm sharing that women love this car for some 
reason!...I'm sure that the girls, of course, also just recognize the pure 
joy in it.  Everyone loves a 7 - the car sounds great, is stupid fast, and 
has no pretense.﻿

comments.author: taipeikartman

comments.text:
The British may not have invented the 2 seat convertible but they pretty 
much perfected it. It's so odd how so many countries make such vastly 
different cars suited to their country. Here in the states we make high 
powered straight line machines or appliances, Japan makes high tech 
economical cars, Germans make luxury high speed touring cars, Brits make 
quick great handling roadsters. I find it unfair how people say cars from 
other countries (especially here) don't do this or that. We all know 
American cars don't handle very well, because we are a country obsessed 
with drag racing. You take a mustang and a jag and put them on a flat road 
and the mustang will walk away. Put them on a twisty road and the Jag will 
leave the mustang behind.﻿
comments.author: Jacksonkellyfreak

comments.text:
Yea they do. You can nitpick who owns who nowadays but cars made in Britain 
for Brits are perfect for twisty narrow little roads. They make what is 
fun, comfortable & well suited the the roads it's going to be on most. In 
America we make big cars suited for wide roads & long highway road trips. 
A Mustang is a real hassle to drive on a narrow winding road but it will go 
in a straight line & it's quite comfortable to hop in & drive 500 miles on 
the freeway. The little British car will eat up that little winding road 
but boy are little British cars uncomfortable on a long road trip. 
We make what suits us. You can't bash a little Lotus or other British car 
for being uncomfy on a road trip. They don't use them for that. You can't 
bash the Mustang for looking like a pregnant cow trying to go down a flight 
of stairs when it's on a narrow twisty road. We don't use then for that.

+twinscroll turbo
 no, the engines in those cars are japanese, but the british have tuned the 
holy piss out of them. lotus uses the toyota 2zz and 2gr engines in their 
cars. the lancer evo and impreza both had their suspension designed by 
prodrive in the uk, and the gtr by mclaren i think. im not totally sure on 
that but i think i read that somewhere in a car magazine or heard it on a 
car show. but im not sure. the brits most definitely have a stranglehold on 
the luxury market with Rolls, Jag, Bentley before VW bought them, and 
Aston. The Germans do luxury very very well, but they can't compare to the 
English burled walnut and corinthian leather, with the lamb's wool mats
comments.author: Jacksonkellyfreak

comments.text:
It has no place for a spare tire, and I've lost too many tires to road 
debris or delamination to leave town without a good spare.
If Elio comes up with a mount for a spare, I'm in, but a high efficiency 
freeway tourer is useless to me if I can't go anywhere. I need a 
Barrel-back Morgan.

comments.text:
+Hunter Newbold It takes influence/is based on popular British sports cars 
of the 60s/70s. Aesthetically speaking its most obvious predecessor is the 
60s Lotus Elan. British sportscars were very popular in the US market, and 
after the decline of the British car industry companies like Mazda created 
the Miata to fill the gap in the market.

comments.text:
+Ryan Mooney mine was a very kipling kind of childhood ... probably the 
last generation from which anyone could say that.  not sure whether that's 
a good thing or a bad thing.  but i had a school friend who restored an old 
morgan 3-wheeler in the hall of his house: that kind of childhood.
comments.author: Hugh Featherstone

comments.text:

comments.author: Ryan Mooney

comments.text:
it's the wye valley.  just go up the gryn fawr valley, not far from 
crickhowell, till you pass llanthony abbey and on up, on up until the 
narrow valley road loses its hedgerows and bursts out onto the pass. from 
there on to hay-on-wye you're in driving heaven. this area is my childhood, 
so i know it well.  i think chris must live in abergavenny, i frequently 
see bits of road from that area in his videos. often with the sugar loaf in 
the background.  great driving country, just remember that ARAF means slow, 
and they mean it!
comments.author: Hugh Featherstone

comments.text:
Jaguar have topped the JD Power survey several times in recent years and 
are consistently ahead of the major German brands in many other surveys. 
All the Jag owners I've spoken to love them and even when they've been 
talking about the badly built Leyland and early Ford era cars they've been 
willing to forgive the cars anything because they loved them so much for 
how they drove when they did work properly.
